title: 2  Gabriel DH
text:
Team members should know their responsibilities and the responsibilities of others
Team members must make agreements on what needs to be done, and who should do it
Team members must be responsible and accountable for completing their own tasks
Team members should have specific goals and a timeline for when to complete them
Team members should have a sense of trust so that they can speak their minds and set goals as a team

title: 2  Gabriel DH
text:
2.2 How to build trust:

Team members should be able to respect each others’ differences and disagree respectfully.
Team members should focus on harnessing the positive aspects of each member as a unique individual

title: 2  Gabriel DH
text:
2.3 Summary:
Effective team work increases efficiency by setting goals that everyone understands, holding members accountable, and understanding how to harness the positive aspects of each member to benefit the project. Trust is necessary for team members to speak freely and share ideas, which supports the project. To build trust, team members must be able to respect each others’ differences and respectfully disagree, while also focusing on the positives that each member brings to the team.
Source:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=n_UhsBZNADM

title: 3  Marvin C
text:
3.1 Summary/Insights
Effective teamwork includes involving all voices in decision making, encouraging an environment where open discussion is possible, and having steps to ensure that conflicts are resolved quickly and productively. Each individual should be able to apply their strengths to the overall progress of the project, such that everyone is able to contribute and feel ownership of the project.
Source: https://skillpath.com/blog/effective-teamwork

title: 4  Madeline W
text:
10 most important aspects to working with a team. 1. Practice Good Communication Skills 2. Work Well with Everyone 3. Clarify Roles, Responsibilities, and Accountabilities 4. Set Clear Goals 5. Value Each Member’s Voice 6. Have a Team Mindset Rather than an I Mindset 7. Be Supportive of All Team Members 8. Recognize the Value of Each Team Member 9. Build Relationships 10. Break Down Barriers
Summary Be a aware and mindful of those you work with and focus on clear and respectful communication
https://www.aces.edu/blog/topics/finance-career/10-tips-for-effective-teamwork-in-the-workplace/

# Summary of datapoints in the US (How many units in the US?)
closed_schools_us <- closed_schools |>
  filter(`Country ID` == "USA") 

dim(closed_schools_us)

[1] 775  19

# Converting character vectors to factors + recoding
tidy_us_schools <- closed_schools_us |>
  mutate(dl_method = as.factor(`Distance learning modalities (Global)`), 
         income_level = `Region 3`, 
         weeks_partial_open = `Weeks partially open`, 
         weeks_closed = `Weeks fully closed`, 
         open_status = fct_recode(Status,
                                  "Academic break" = "break",
                                  "Partially open" = "partial",
                                  "Fully open" = "full"), 
         date = Date) |>
  select(date, income_level, open_status, dl_method, weeks_partial_open, weeks_closed)

Warning: There was 1 warning in `mutate()`.
ℹ In argument: `open_status = fct_recode(...)`.
Caused by warning:
! Unknown levels in `f`: break, partial, full

head(tidy_us_schools, 5)

# A tibble: 5 × 6
  date       income_level  open_status dl_method weeks_partial_open weeks_closed
  <date>     <chr>         <fct>       <fct>                  <dbl>        <dbl>
1 2020-02-16 WB: High inc… Fully open  Online +…                 77            0
2 2020-02-17 WB: High inc… Fully open  Online +…                 77            0
3 2020-02-18 WB: High inc… Fully open  Online +…                 77            0
4 2020-02-19 WB: High inc… Fully open  Online +…                 77            0
5 2020-02-20 WB: High inc… Fully open  Online +…                 77            0



# What is the distribution of our factors (status, dl_method)?

tidy_us_schools |>
  ggplot(aes(x = dl_method)) +
  geom_bar()






# The designated distance learning method throughout our time period was Online+TV

tidy_us_schools |>
  ggplot(aes(x = open_status)) +
  geom_bar()






# The majority of the time schools were partially open


# How did open status change over the course of our time period?

tidy_us_schools |>
  ggplot(aes(y = date, fill = open_status)) +
  geom_bar()








nld_schools <- closed_schools |>
  filter(Country == 'Netherlands')


# Importing final dataset
covid <- read_csv("../../data/clean_covid.csv")

# Pivoting final dataset to include subject category
clean_covid <- covid |>
  pivot_longer(cols = c(spelling_value, reading_value, math_value),
               names_to = 'subject',
               values_to = 'scores_diff',
               names_pattern = "(.*)_value",
               names_transform = list(subject = as.factor))


unique(clean_covid$VARIABLES)

[12] "Observations"                              
[13] "R-squared"                                 
[14] "Clusters"                                  

# Removing unnecessary observations 
factored_covid <- clean_covid |>
  filter(!(VARIABLES %in% c("Constant", "Observations", "R-squared", "Clusters")))

covid <- read_csv("../../data/clean_covid_formatted.csv")

• `` -> `...1`



# Viz 4 final
covid |>
  select(subject, grade,`COVID-19 year * Parental education high`, `COVID-19 year * Parental education medium`) |>
  pivot_longer(cols = c(-subject, -grade),
               names_to = "education_level",
               values_to = "scores_diff") |>
   mutate(education_level = as.factor(str_to_sentence(str_extract(education_level, "medium|high")))) |>
  mutate(education_level = fct_relevel(education_level, c("Medium", "High")),
         subject = as.factor(subject)) |>
  group_by(education_level, subject) |>
  summarize(mean_scores_diff = mean(scores_diff)) |>
  ggplot(aes(y = mean_scores_diff, x = education_level)) +
  geom_col() +
  facet_wrap(~subject) +
  labs(x = "Parental Education Level",
       y = "Average Change in Scores During Covid",
       title = "Comparing the Change in Exam Scores during Covid by Parental Education Level")

`summarise()` has grouped output by 'education_level'. You can override using
the `.groups` argument.









# Viz 3 
covid |>
  select(subject, grade,education_medium, education_high) |>
  pivot_longer(cols = c(-subject, -grade),
               names_to = "education_level",
               values_to = "scores_diff") |> 
  mutate(education_level = as.factor(str_to_sentence(str_extract(education_level, "medium|high")))) |>
  mutate(education_level = fct_relevel(education_level, c("Medium", "High")),
         subject = as.factor(subject)) |>
  group_by(education_level, subject) |>
  summarize(mean_scores_diff = mean(scores_diff)) |>
  ggplot(aes(y = mean_scores_diff, x = education_level)) +
  geom_col() +
  facet_wrap(~subject) +
  labs(x = "Parental Education Level",
       y = "Average Change in Scores Before Covid",
       title = "Comparing the Change in Exam Scores Before Covid by Parental Education Level")

`summarise()` has grouped output by 'education_level'. You can override using
the `.groups` argument.

title: Appendix A — Proposal
text:
Proposal: Names: Madeline Willett, Ruth Lavan, Marvin Contreras, Gabriel Donelly Higgins
Title: Did Covid Cook our Kids? Looking at the relationship between the Covid-19 pandemic education
Short Description: We want to explore the impact the covid 19 and the following lockdown had on the education of students. We are focusing on the impact of covid on american students during and around the time of lockdown and the pandemic.
Inspiration: Our own experience with covid impacting our education experience.



table

title: Appendix B — Case Study
text:
Multiple research questions that culminate in one final conclusion
Consistent coloring to distinguish between iPhone and Android category
Included R code in his final website (may be distracting to a general audience)
Inconsistent formatting of visualizations
Lots of visualizations that correspond to different questions (variety of viz types as well)
The conclusion is well-supported by the visualizations, nothing seems unrelated
